section.title: Text Search
section.para: Open a new Search window with C f and enter the word or phrase you wish to search for in the search box.
Alternatively, select a word or phrase in the pane, pane or pane and hit Cf. The selection is automatically entered in the search box.
You can have several Search windows open at the same time. Call the last Search window with SCf.
Click the dropdown arrow of the Search for box to access the last 10 searches.
Click on Search or hit Enter when the search field is selected to launch the search.
The matches will be displayed in bold blue.
The Search window has its own menus:

listitem.para: File > Search for selection ( C f ): the current selection is inserted in the search field.
File > Close ( C w ): close the search window (in the same way as Esc)
Edit > Insert source ( S C i ): insert current segment source.
Edit > Replace with source ( S C r ): replace with current segment source.
Edit > Create Glossary Entry ( S C g ): add a new glossary item. See for details.
Edit > Reset Options: reset the Search window options.

section.title: Search methods and options
section.para: Select the method using the radio buttons. The following search methods are available:

listitem.para: Search for the string exactly as it has been entered in the search field.
It is the equivalent of a web search surrounded by quotation marks.
Search for segments containing all the space-separated strings as if they were separate keywords.
It is the equivalent of a web search without quotation marks.
The search string will be treated as a regular expression.
Regular expressions are a very powerful way to search for complex or general patterns and not exact strings. See for details.

section.para: In both exact and keyword searches, the wild card search characters * and ? can be used:

listitem.para: '*' matches zero or more characters, from the current position in a given word to its end. The search term 'run*' for example would match words 'run', 'runs' and 'running'.
'?' matches any single character. For instance, 'run?' would match the word 'runs' and 'runn' in the word 'running'.

warning.para: '*' and '?' have a special meaning in regular expressions, so wild card search, as described here, applies to exact and keyword search only.

When searching files (as opposed to translation memories), OmegaT restricts the search to files in supported file formats. Consequently, although OmegaT supports tmx as a TM format but not as a source file format, it does not include them in the files search.

section.para: If you click on the button Advanced options additional criteria such as: person who authored or changed the translation, date of translation (modification), exclusion of orphan segments, etc. can be selected.
When Full/Half width char insensitive option is checked, searches for fullwidth forms (CJK characters) will match halfwidth forms and vice versa.
Number of matching segments sets the maximum number of matched displayed in the search result area.

section.title: Search results display
section.para: Matches are displayed in order of appearance in the project. Translated segments are displayed with the original text at the top and the translated text at the bottom, untranslated segments are displayed as the source only.
In the search window, you can use standard shortcuts ( C n , C p ) to move from one segment to another.
Double-click on a segment to open it in the .
Check Auto-sync with Editor to have selected segments automatically opened in the Editor.
Check Back to the initial segment on close to automatically go back to the segment where you were when you started the search, after you close the window.

section.title: Filter
section.para: Click on the button to filter matching segments in the . To remove the filter, press Remove filter or reload the project.
